text:
Robyn: Today, we're here
with Margaret A. Neale. She is the Adams
Distinguished Professor

of Management Emerita at
Stanford University's Graduate School of Business. Her bio is linked
in the dashboard.

We have a lot of great,
wonderful material here for you today, and we might run over.

For the first time
ever, I'm saying that. Because I think it's
important for everyone to be able to stay
on if they can. If not, you're going
to get the recording.

Stay on for Q&A. Please
submit the questions. I think you're going to
have lots of things to ask. Maggie, thanks so much for
being here today with us.

And take it away. MARGARET NEALE:
Well, thanks, Robyn. And thanks for joining me today.

I'm actually speaking
from a hotel room in Oregon, where I'm taking
a little bit of a holiday.

But I will just tell you that
there is a lot of content, and I want to apologize
in advance if it just

feels like a fire hose because
there's so many things I want to talk to you about. And so the first
thing I want to do,

because my area is negotiation,
and the courses that I teach are in negotiation.

So one of the things I
want you to think about is that one of the challenges
we face and the way people think

about negotiation is they
think about it as a battle. And oftentimes, even
more constraining,

they think about
it as an activity that they engage in if they
were negotiating a contract or if they were negotiating
a compensation plan

for new job or a promotion. But it's so much
broader than that. But what happens is when people
say the word negotiation,

the sense we get is that
this is going to be a fight. We're going to fight. And so we look at
negotiation as this process,

where I'm going to try to get
stuff from you that you don't want me to have, and I'm
going to try to keep you from getting my stuff.

And if that's how you
think about negotiation, you're doing yourself
a disservice. Because what happens when
you take that mindset is that

becomes a filter through which
you evaluate your counterpart. And because they are the
enemy, they are the other,

they are what's keeping you from
getting more of what you want, you're going to
interpret their behaviors

in an adversarial
and malevolent way. And oftentimes, when you are
in that negotiation mindset,

you begin to focus
on single issues, like a financial nature, like
contracts, and compensation,

and things like that. And you don't think broadly
about what's possible. And that's what I want to
talk to you about today

is think about negotiation
as much more than simply figuring out a price, or a
salary range, or a contract.

It's much more than that. So I want you to
broaden your definition of what is negotiation.

And that is that
negotiation is influence. It's all about
getting a decision

that meets your needs
better and maybe the needs of your counterparts as well.

So it's actually about
improving a situation in which you and your
counterparts find yourselves.

So it's the process,
where two or more people decide what
each is willing to give

and hopes to get in
their interaction, and through a process of mutual
influence and persuasion.
Again, it's influence. There's no command and control. I can't force you to say yes.

But what I want to do is I want
to exchange proposals and find a solution that makes it easy
for both of us to say yes.

Now, what that means
is that in doing that, I'm going to suggest a strategy
that I think is really useful,

and that is to change
your mindset from looking at negotiations, these
kinds of influence

attempts that you
make when you don't have command and control to
collaborative problem solving.

Remember that negotiations
are interdependent. Influence is interdependent.

You and your counterpart
must voluntarily agree to the outcome. And especially if
you're negotiating

with folks who are either
equal to or above you in the organization,
it's a voluntary process.

And it acknowledges that you
don't have command and control. So what you want
to do is you want

to create a solution, where you
are better off because there's been some changes, or
some things that you want,

or some new information. You're better off than the
status quo or your alternatives,

where your counterpart is better
off because of those changes. But certainly not worse off.

But here's the important point. And this is number three. You want to frame the
proposals that you make to them as solutions to a
problem that you and they have.

It's about both a solution
to a problem that they have. Because one of the things that
becomes really critical when

you're trying to get someone
to move in a direction, is you need to understand
what their interests are,

what their preferences are,
what their challenges are, what their constraints are.

Now, it turns out this is
actually a challenging process. Because it turns out that, if
you think you're negotiating,

then you get in this
battle mentality. So just set that aside and
think about these kinds

of interactions as
collaborative problem solving, and then think about how
can I help my counterpart

while helping myself be better. So you need to
create options here.

And that's really the--
you need to be creative. And this is what's a
challenge about this. Because in order to
embrace this perspective,

you've got to think
about basically what's important to
your counterpart, but also what's
important to you.

And the creativity comes
in merging those two sets of interests, where
you're able to find

a solution that where they
think they're going to improve and you know you're
going to improve.

So that's the sweet spot. But that takes planning
and preparation. And that takes creativity.

You can't just simply do kind of
a off the top of your head knee jerk. You've got to prepare.

So if you take this
perspective, you can influence outcomes
with your subordinates,

with your superiors,
with your peers. And you can improve the
projects that you're

on by making them
more effective given the scenario, the environment,
the situation that you're in.

But as you expand your
opportunities here, you really need
to think carefully

about what it is that will
make you first better off. And so what I want you
to think about here

is I want you to
think about the goal. The goal is not
simply to get along.

The goal is not
simply to acquiesce if someone makes a demand
of you to just say yes. What the goal is to
get a better outcome.

For example, an
improved allocation of scarce resources for
you or your project,

a more workable solution or a
better working relationship. Those are all things
that you can negotiate,

you can problem solve around. And in doing so, you can
improve your standing

in the organization, you're
standing with your superiors, you're standing with
your subordinates.

So what you need to think
about, and part of the planning you need to think about is what
are the boundaries that affect

what you're trying to achieve. And so I'm going to give you
three boundaries that you

need to think about. And the first boundary
is what happens if you can't make these
kinds of adjustments.

So what's your
fallback position? You really need to understand
that alternative that is what

happens to you if perhaps you're
given-- you're given a new--

a new aspect of your
task or your project. And there's nothing happens,
but you just say yes.

So what does that
look like for you? And also, what you need
to think about is-- a second point is, well,
what's the worst thing

that you could be happy with? What's that point, where you
go from a situation you'd like to say no to to one
that you could say yes to?

So you want to think about
where that tipping point is. Because that tipping point is
a really important position

for you to understand to
know when you're going to-- you at least don't
have to push as hard.

Because you've gotten above
that point where you say, I'm better off here. But that's not where
you want to stop.

Where you want to-- what you also want
to think about, and I think this is actually
one of the most critical aspects

of these three boundaries,
is what's a stretch goal? So as you are preparing for
this meeting with your superior,

or a peer, or even
a subordinate, what would a really good
outcome look like for you given

the situation that you're in? So you want to
basically set that set that aspiration in
terms of where you are,

the experience that you
have, your environment, but what would be a really
good outcome for you? What kind of resources
might you be able to garner?

What kind of
outcomes might you be able to achieve if you were able
to get those resources that you

need or able to find the
additional folks that you need, or able to get more
financial resources?

What might you be
able to do to improve the quality of the projects
of which you are a part?

So I'm going to
give you and suggest that there are two routes
that we can follow to improve

your negotiated outcomes, to
improve your influence attempts basically. And I want to talk
about number one,

is the use of justifications. Explaining why you're
doing what you're doing.

And with that comes
the importance of understanding the
power of the ask.

And then we're going
to talk about how to avoid scope creep through
the use of packaging.

So that's a really
important one as well. So let's get started
on those two. So the way I want to talk about
influence through justifications

and the power of
the ask is, I want to demonstrate to
you through the use

of a classic social
psych experiment. Now, when I say
classic, I will readily

admit that this study
was done decades ago. In fact, I suspect this study
was published before many of you

were born. Doesn't mean it's wrong. It just means we call
it a classic now.
So here's the study.

Researchers were asked
to go to organizations and find the copy room.

Now, this study actually
was conducted in 1977. So yes, it is old.

And when the researchers
found the copy room, they were asked to
wait until there

was a line at the copy machine. And for those of you, you
may have heard about this. I certainly live this.

When I was a graduate
student, when I was an employee, and a
pretty low status employee.

We would have to stand in
line at the copy machine making copies. That was one of the jobs
that I did a lot of.

Or you are trying
to study for finals, and you had to make
copies of things, and there was a copy
machine in the library, and you stood in line.

And so the question-- so the researchers went
into these organizations

and found the room with the
copy machine and waited. And they waited until there
was a line at the copy machine.

And then they went
to the person who was about to step
up to make copies. And basically, they were
told by the study designer,

I want you to go in and see if
you can get that person who's about to step up
to the copy machine to let you cut in front
of them, but you can only

use one of three
possible strategies. Here are the three strategies. First is, we're going
to do the simple ask.

May I use the copy machine? OK. The second strategy
is, you're going

to ask to use the copy machine. May I use the copy machine? And then you're going to say a
reasonable explanation for why

you're making this ask,
may I use the copy machine. Because I'm in a real rush.

And then the third
strategy is make the ask, but give a stupid justification.

May I use the copy machine
because I need to make copies. And so what then
she said, is you

need to then tally
how many people allow you to step in front of them
with each of these three

strategies. OK, so that was the study. So they went out into
the organizations. They found the copy machines.

Researchers got all
this data, and then they came back and analyzed it. So let's see what they found.

So here's the first one. First one is may I
use the copy machine. Now, this is just
straightforward

asking for what they wanted. Now, I want you to
think for a minute. And I want each
of you, as you're

listening to me, to think
about what's the problem-- what's the percentage of
folks who think said yes.

Now, this is 1977. In the US. What percent of folks,
when they were asked,

may I use the copy
machine, said, sure, and let people step
in front of them?

Well, would it surprise
you that the answer was 60% of folks said yes.

And if it did, that's
interesting, right. Because most of us are
surprised by that number.

We're surprised because we
think that that's a real--

I mean, that's kind of
a rude, weird thing. Let me just cut in line. May I use the copy machine. But what this
represents, and I think

this is so critical to
your understanding of how to be influential in
your organizations,
this is the power of the ask. These people were strangers.

They didn't have any kind of
history with these people. They didn't have a
future with these people. They just stepped up
to them and said, may
I use the copy machine. And 60% of folks said, yes.

We often avoid asking
for what we want. We avoid because we think
people won't say yes to that.

We think they will
be inconvenienced. We think somehow they
will think of us as weak.

But what I want
to suggest to you is that if you don't ask for
what you want, how will others

know what it is you want? If you don't ask
for what you want, then you're really basically
forcing them to mind read.

And we, human beings, are
terrible at this mind reading thing. But if you don't ask for
what you want, who will?

And that's also important. Because sometimes, your asks can
change the entire conversation.

And what I think is
even more surprising for most folks is that
people dramatically

underestimate how willing
people are to accommodate. You see, when you
ask for something,

it turns out people want to
grant those requests if they can. It gives the grantor
a sense of agency,

a sense of having control
and influence in their lives. And so part of asking
is really letting

people feel good about helping. And there was actually
while this study was done in the 1970s, you'll see at the
bottom left of the screen here

on my slides that there was
a study that was recently conducted that actually said
people love to be able to help.

And they're to be able to--
they love being able to say, I was able to do something.

And so one of the
things that I've done in my own personal
life, as well as because of the research and
my own experience

since learning of
this research, is that I ask for what
I want even when

I think it is really unlikely
that they're going to say yes.

But I know if I don't ask,
I already know the answer. And if I do ask, I'm
somewhat surprised

a lot of times about how
willing people are to say, sure, I can do that. Or let me help you.

Or here's a way we can try
to find a solution for that. So I am a real proponent
of the power of the ask.

All right. So let's go to the second one. And here is where we first
use the justification.

So the question is, may
I use the copy machine? And then there's a justification
of why I'm making this ask.
Because I'm in a real rush. What do you think? What did people do here?
What percent of folks said yes? Well, 92%.

Now, I know that
there are many of you

out there who are looking with a
jaundiced eye at these results. You're saying, these
wouldn't hold in my culture,

in my company, or whatever. People are not
going to be either. Only 60%. We might have more
people say yes or less

than we might be much,
much, much lower. These numbers are not sacred. This 60% is not a sacred number.

What is important to
see here is the delta between asking alone and
asking with a justification.

A 50% increase in compliance. So part of what you
want to think about here

is the importance of giving
people an explanation for why
you're doing what you're doing. A simple request is good. It's important. It's a great first step.

But I'm also going
to suggest that it's really critical for you
to actually explain why

you're doing what you're doing. And I'm a real
proponent of this. I tell people the thinking
process underlying my position,

the things I'm
hoping to achieve, why I'm doing what I'm doing. And I think that
kind of transparency

actually enhances
people's willingness to accommodate your requests.

OK, let's go to the third one. Now, this is kind
of crazy, right. This is like, may I
use the copy machine?

Because I need to make copies. Seriously, everybody in
line needs to make copies.

But what percent of people
here do you think said yes?

Well, this may surprise you. Because actually,
the number was 91%.

So there's not a whole lot
of difference between-- in this situation
between the justification

that's reasonable
and a justification that's just nonsense. But if you don't
believe these numbers,

think about your
experience in the TSA line. Have you ever been
in a TSA line,

or have you been that
person in the TSA line who was late and goes running
up to the line and says, excuse me, excuse me,
can I cut in line?

I need to make a flight. Well, that's the same thing. We're all in this
line to make a flight.

Because today is Tuesday,
and I'm here to fly. I'm not here to just stand
in line at the airport

because that's what I do. No. But what happens is,
what appears to happen, what the researchers
have found is

that people will
hear the request, may I use the copy machine?
May I cut in line because-- and then they stop listening.

Because They've already
made the decision. You see, these
kinds of decisions. Cutting in front-- cutting
in line in the copy machine,

cutting in line in the
TSA line, these are not mission critical decisions. And so what happens is people
are like-- they've already

made the decision. They're not going to engage that
very costly, cognitive resources in order to accommodate
thinking about well, what

did they just say? Make copies? Well, we're all here to do that. No, it's not worth it. You've already decided,
and then you move on.

Now, it turns out that
justifications, sometimes

their mere presence
in, especially in trivial kinds
of decisions, are more powerful than the
justification that you use.

But most of us are thinking
about justifications when we have decisions
that are actually

going to be scrutinized, people
are going to pay attention. And so when that's
the case, you need

to have more objective
justifications. You need to explain why. And explaining why can mitigate
your counterpart's resistance

to behaviors they're
not expecting from you. Explaining why helps. And the reason it helps is
because it provides the story
that you want to tell. It gives them a narrative. They don't have to make it up.

You're telling them why you're
doing what you're doing. And that's probably a
whole lot more appropriate

story or narrative than
the one they might come up with on their own.

Now, second,
avoiding scope creep through the power
of the package. All right.

So turns out that oftentimes,
when we're trying to enlarge

or trying to improve the
quality of the decisions and how we make them, we go
by focusing a single issue

at a time. I'm concerned I don't have
enough marketing budget. Let's talk about the
marketing budget. I'm concerned that
my resources here,

in terms of my support staff,
are not the quality that I need, or I'm concerned
that I'm not getting

the time on the
computers that I need. Whatever it is. But we do it one at a time.

So what I want
you to think about is to think about
creating value requires

that we think about these
issues as a package. Rather than engaging
each issue by itself,

which is kind of a yes or a no
issue, a win or a lose issue, you want to think about
multiple issues considered

simultaneously. So you want to have a package. Here's the package
of resources that we

can craft that can
help me improve the project in terms
of its performance

or in terms of its timeliness. You might be able to
craft that prep package,

but that requires
that you understand what's important to you
in that, but also what's

important to your counterpart. And what you're
looking for are ways that aren't very
costly to you, that

are beneficial to
your counterpart, and ways that are not
very costly to them,

that are beneficial to you. And part of what we
want to try to find is that sweet spot, where
you can make those trades.

But you need multiple
issues within your package to be able to make those trades.

That means you need
to set priorities. And what you're looking
for are those asymmetries.

What's more important to
you, less important to them. What's less important to them
and more important to you. Those are the easy ones.

And then what you
want to do is you want to make a proposal that
incorporates all of these.

Because what that
does is it allows you to identify and perhaps
extract additional resources

to if you're getting
that scope creep, it's not just the frog
in the boiling water

kind of thing or frog in
the hot water that boils. Eventually, it kind of dies. But what happens
is, is that you,

then as the scope of
the project enlarges, so do the resources
associated with that project.

And so part of it
is understanding that we can have
that negotiation, we can have that conversation,
and in fact get more resources

as the project requires them,
rather than just simply going along and sitting in that
hot water as it gets hotter,

and hotter, and hotter. So you shouldn't be afraid
to add issues and be creative about that
because you want

to be expansive in
the number of issues that you bring to the
table, because that allows more of this
opportunity for making trades.

Now, as you bring more
issues to the table, the interaction
becomes more complex.

Absolutely. And sometimes, it's
so complex that people begin making mistakes,
and you get too much--

there's too much
cognitive demand on it. If your contracts
are too complex, it's really hard to keep them
all in your head, all the issues

all at once. So what you need to do is
think about this theoretically and make it smaller.

So you may not have all the
issues in a particular package. We call it a chunk. So form chunks three
issues at a time.

Maybe we can all deal with
three issues at a time. And think about that chunk. And if you have lots
of other issues,

think about that negotiation. Think about that chunk. Put it aside. Once you've got it agreed to,
don't take it off the table.

Put it aside. The reason I'm telling you
not to take it off the table is because you've got lots
of other chunks to agree to.

Once you got all the
chunks agreed to, then put it all back together,
and make sure it makes sense. Because time moves on,
the environments change.

And if we've learned nothing
from COVID, what we should learn is we don't predict
the future very well. So you want to make sure
that by the time you

finish the whole negotiation,
everything still makes sense.

So here are the five tips we
talked about in the first slide. First is consider expanding
your perspective on negotiation

from negotiation as
battle to negotiation as collaborative
problem solving.

Know what your goal is
and what you can and can't accommodate in the interaction
before you engage with it.

Understand the environment
in which you're a part. Leverage the power of the ask.

Ask for what you want. And if there's nothing else
you take from this little time

together, this is an important--
this is the important lesson. Ask, ask, ask.

And let me just add to that. Use justifications. Explain to people why you
are doing what you are doing.

Give them an
alternative narrative. That's the narrative
you want them

to have as opposed to the
narrative that they create. And finally, package.

Multi issues are your friend. This is the way you
can create value. And when you do that,
you may find yourselves

being able to not only
create more value, but claim a bigger
share of that pie in terms of your status, your
efficacy, your efficiency

in the organization, and the
way in which you are perceived by your workers,
your counterparts,

and your superiors. Now, if you want to know
more, a couple of things

I'm going to suggest. If you haven't read Robert
Cialdini's book on Influence,

this one-- the 2009 was the
last revision of his book that he did before he
went and retired emeritus.

I'd strongly recommend
that you read this book. This is an amazing--
he's done so much research about influence, and
he's got some great stories,

and he's an amazing writer. So do that. I think this next book
is really good too.

It happens to be my book. Getting more of what you want. How the secrets of economics
and psychology can help you

negotiate anything in
business and in life. And then also, there's a website
associated with the book called

gettingmoreofwhatyouwant.com,
which has more articles, it has podcasts, it has
video clips, it has articles

that I've written. My colleague and I
are there in video. All that's up there. You're welcome to peruse it.

And with that, I'm going to
turn it back over to Robin.

Robyn: Maggie, thanks
so much for that.

Every time you
share your insights, I always learn something more. So thank you so much.

Everyone, we have a couple of
questions that have come in. I'm going to try to put
them in different pieces,

and I'm going to
put them together in a more robust question. While we're talking
here, in the dashboard

is linked Maggie's course,
getting more of what you want. So you can see that there. You can see her bio there.

We are at 9:30 right now, but
we're going to stay on a couple extra minutes and
answer some questions. Maggie, I really
appreciated and it

seems like other people
really appreciated about what you said about
the power of the ask. 100%.

You don't ask, you
already know the answer to it, which is going
to be no because you haven't asked the question. Something that people
are struggling with

and wonder how you handle this. So you said in
your personal life, you've really learned
the power of the ask.

How do you balance-- because I think that this
is common amongst people. How do you balance
negotiating against yourself?

For example, the
power of the ask. Let's say you're
leading a project. You're leading a team.

Your hands a month
ago, and you heard from senior leadership
about how tight things are, and this, and that.

Now, you want to ask for
what your project needs, but also you're
really wondering, how is this ask going to go up
against what I already going on

in the organization? Am I going to make people mad? Am I going to cross a line and
make bring them to the point of, I don't even know why this
person is asking this?

Could you speak to that? MARGARET NEALE: Sure. And that requires you
focusing on that aspect

of collaborative
problem solving, which is what are the interests
of your counterpart and what are the
constraints they face.

That doesn't mean
you shouldn't ask. Because I can tell
you, I have been in so many situations in my life
where people said oh, there's

no opportunity here. Well, OK, maybe there's not
generally opportunities,

but there are always,
for good enough ideas, for enough sort of insight
and sort of creativity,

there are ways people
find resources. But again, it's up to you
to be creative in that,

to understand your counterpart
and to understand where the opportunities that exist.

And so this is what I tell
my students all the time. And they often talk to me about,
compensation, negotiation,

compensation plans. And they're like,
I want more money. And I said, well,
more money is good. Absolutely. Maybe there's some
constraints there.

But when you ask for other
things, other resources that can help the
organization or can help

you do a better--
you make a better contribution to
the organization, people are going to listen.

They're going to consider that. And while this is what the
other benefit of a package is. While you may not
get everything,

you're probably not
going to get zero. You're probably going
to get something. So the point is you need
to ask and realize that you

need to figure out how to ask. And you have to ask in a
way that says to the person, I care about this organization,
I care about my group,

I care about the project,
and I want to make it better. And here's what we can
do to make this better.

Robyn: I think that's great. So being collaborative, being
open, and letting them know,

hey, I'm aware-- I'm aware a month ago, we
had this all hands meeting, and things are tight. Here's why this is important.

And then as you said, bring
in those justifications. MARGARET NEALE: Right Robyn: OK. The other questions that
seem to be bubbling up

are around packaging. Because I think like
me, like other people,

it's so much more linear
to think of one at a time, but it doesn't really
serve our purpose.

So the packaging. How can we, as individuals,
get better at packaging?

Are we writing it down? Are we boiling it down? We heard that money
was a big constraint.

So then we're
upleveling something. How do you get
better at that other than getting some part of it
is in your plan right away?

MARGARET NEALE: Yeah. Part of it is in your planning. Your planning process before
you even begin the conversation. So you should be in there.

And that's what the
creativity is around. Think expansively
about what resources

are available in
the organization or could be available
in the organization.

You don't need to limit
yourself to the obvious stuff. What could be available,
what's creative,

out of the box thinking
